# Connecting with Opal data server
## Login to server and assign study data
```{r, echo=FALSE}
#Load Opal R library
library(opal)
library(dplyr)
library(epiDisplay)
# Create an opal object with the login information
erasmus_opal <- opal.login()
#Login to Opal server and assign the content of the GLOBE table(s) to your RStudio environment
# GLOBE1991
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'GLOBE1991', 'GLOBE.GLOBE1991', variables= list("")) 
GLOBE1991 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'GLOBE1991')
# GLOBE1997
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'GLOBE1997', 'GLOBE.GLOBE1997',variables=list("")) 
GLOBE1997 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'GLOBE1997')

# GLOBE2004
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'GLOBE_2004_socialenvironment_2006', 'GLOBE.GLOBE_2004_socialenvironment_2006', variables=list("URBANIZATION_GRADE_2006","PROPORTION_MEN_2006","PROPORTION_WOMEN_2006","PROPORTION_65_OLDER_2006","PROPORTION_UNMARIED_2008","PROPORTION_MARIED_2008","PROPORTION_DIVORCED_2008","PROPORTION_WIDOWED_2008","AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006","AVERAGE_VALUE_DWELLINGS_2006","AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005","PROPORTION_INCOME_RECIPIENTS_200","PROPORTION_SOCSECBEN_2006","PROPORTION_DISABILITY_BENEFIT_20","PROPORTION_UNEMPLOYMENT_BENEFIT", "MUNICIPALITY_CODE_2006", "NEIGHBORHOOD_CODE_2006","PC4_CODE_2006","PC6_CODE_2006"))
GLOBE2004 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'GLOBE_2004_socialenvironment_2006')

# GLOBE2011
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'GLOBE_2011_socialenvironment_2011', 'GLOBE.GLOBE_2011_socialenvironment_2011', variables =list("URBANIZATION_GRADE_2011","PROPORTION_MEN_2011","PROPORTION_WOMEN_2011","PROPORTION_65_OLDER_2011","PROPORTION_UNMARIED_2011","PROPORTION_MARIED_2011","PROPORTION_DIVORCED_2011","PROPORTION_WIDOWED_2011","AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2011","AVERAGE_VALUE_DWELLINGS_2011","PROPORTION_UNOCCUPIED_DWELLINGS","AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2011","PROPORTION_INCOME_RECIPIENTS_201","PROPORTION_SOCSECBEN_2010","PROPORTION_DISABILITY_BENEFIT_20","PROPORTION_UNEMPLOYMENT_BENEFIT","PROPORTION_LOW_EDUCATION_2014","PROPORTION_INTERMEDIATE_EDUCATIO","PROPORTION_HIGH_EDUCATION_2014","NUMBER_CRIMINAL_OFFENSES_PER_100","NUMBER_VANDALISM_PUBLIC_ORDER_PE","NUMBER_VIOLENT_CRIMES_SEXUAL_OFF","MUNICIPALITY_CODE_2011", "NEIGHBORHOOD_CODE_2011", "PC4_CODE_2011","PC6_CODE_2011"))
GLOBE2011 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'GLOBE_2011_socialenvironment_2011')

# GLOBE2014
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'GLOBE_2014_socialenvironment_2011', 'GLOBE.GLOBE_2014_socialenvironment_2011', variables =list("URBANIZATION_GRADE_2011","PROPORTION_MEN_2011","PROPORTION_WOMEN_2011","PROPORTION_65_OLDER_2011","PROPORTION_UNMARIED_2011","PROPORTION_MARIED_2011","PROPORTION_DIVORCED_2011","PROPORTION_WIDOWED_2011","AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2011","AVERAGE_VALUE_DWELLINGS_2011","PROPORTION_UNOCCUPIED_DWELLINGS","AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2011","PROPORTION_INCOME_RECIPIENTS_201","PROPORTION_SOCSECBEN_2010","PROPORTION_DISABILITY_BENEFIT_20","PROPORTION_UNEMPLOYMENT_BENEFIT","PROPORTION_LOW_EDUCATION_2014","PROPORTION_INTERMEDIATE_EDUCATIO","PROPORTION_HIGH_EDUCATION_2014","NUMBER_CRIMINAL_OFFENSES_PER_100","NUMBER_VANDALISM_PUBLIC_ORDER_PE","NUMBER_VIOLENT_CRIMES_SEXUAL_OFF","MUNICIPALITY_CODE_2011", "NEIGHBORHOOD_CODE_2011", "PC4_CODE_2011","PC6_CODE_2011"))
GLOBE2014 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'GLOBE_2014_socialenvironment_2011')
```
## Assign participant id as first column of your harmonized dataframes
```{r, echo=FALSE}
socenv_GLOBE_0 <- data.frame(id = GLOBE1991$id)
socenv_GLOBE_1 <- data.frame(id = GLOBE1997$id)
socenv_GLOBE_2 <- data.frame(id = GLOBE2004$id)
socenv_GLOBE_3 <- data.frame(id = GLOBE2011$id)
socenv_GLOBE_4 <- data.frame(id = GLOBE2014$id)
```

## When you are done with your work, logout of Opal server
```{r, echo=FALSE}
opal.logout(erasmus_opal) 
```

**Variable type**: integer
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:

**Harmonization comment**:  
For GLOBE, these data are available for neighbourhoods in 2006 and 2011. This variable was already available in the original data source. This variable has been linked to cohort respondents using their 6-digit postal code. References of all data sources are listed in the WP7 deliverable report. ### **Variable label**: Average income in 1000 euros (dichotomized)  
**Variable name**: socenv_av_incdich1000_2 
**Variable description**: Average income in 1000 euros of residents in residential area (dichotomized: below/above country-specific mean household income).    
**Variable type**: integer     
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 | Less than or equal to country-specific mean household income
1 | Greater than country-specific mean household income   

**Harmonization status**: complete  
**Harmonization comment**: 
We dichotomized average net yearly income in 1000 euros of residents in 2005 in the neighbourhood by comparing it with the country-specific net mean household income (OECD-data) in 2005 (€23.895). OECD uses a square root scale which is a scale that adjusts the household income for household size by dividing the total household income by the square root of household size. We take this correction into account and we also make the assumption that when the average household size is 2 or above, there are 2 income earners in the household.
The income variable has been calculated as follows: 
if hh_size<2, income_correction= income*hh_size/sqrt(hh_size)
if hh_size>=2, income_correction= income*2/sqrt(hh_size)
Subsequently, the corrected income variable has been compared with the OECD value.
Here, the final variable is linked to GLOBE participants at wave 2004.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE} 
socenv_GLOBE_2$socenv_av_incdich1000_2 <-
ifelse((as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006))<2, as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)*as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006)/sqrt(as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006)), as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)*2/sqrt(as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006)))

socenv_GLOBE_2$socenv_av_incdich1000_2 <-
ifelse(as.numeric(socenv_GLOBE_2$socenv_av_incdich1000_2) > 23.895, 1, 0)

```       



### **Variable label**: Average income in 1000 euros (dichotomized)  
**Variable name**: socenv_av_incdich1000_3 
**Variable description**: Average income in 1000 euros of residents in residential area (dichotomized: below/above country-specific mean household income).    
**Variable type**: integer     
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 | Less than or equal to country-specific mean household income
1 | Greater than country-specific mean household income   

**Harmonization status**: complete  
**Harmonization comment**: 
We dichotomized average gross yearly income in 1000 euros of residents in 2011 in the neighbourhood by comparing it with the country-specific mean gross household income (data from Statistics Netherlands) in 2011 (€60400). 
We make the assumption that when the average household size is 2 or above, there are 2 income earners in the household.
The income variable has been calculated as follows: 
if hh_size<2, income_correction= income*hh_size
if hh_size>=2, income_correction= income*2
Subsequently, the income variable has been compared with the country-specific mean gross household income.
Here, the final variable is linked to GLOBE participants at wave 2011.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
socenv_GLOBE_3$socenv_av_incdich1000_3 <-
ifelse((as.numeric(GLOBE2011$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2011))<2, as.numeric(GLOBE2011$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2011)*as.numeric(GLOBE2011$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2011), as.numeric(GLOBE2011$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2011)*2) 

socenv_GLOBE_3$socenv_av_incdich1000_3 <-
ifelse(as.numeric(socenv_GLOBE_3$socenv_av_incdich1000_3) > 60.400, 1, 0)

```

### **Variable label**: Average income in 1000 euros (Z standardised)  
**Variable name**: socenv_av_inc1000Z_2  
**Variable description**: Average income in 1000 euros of residents in residential area (standardized: mean=0 and sd=1).
**Variable type**: integer     
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Harmonization status**: complete  
**Harmonization comment**: 
We standardized average net year income in 1000 euros of residents in 2005 in the neighbourhood by using the formula: Z=(x-y)/o (Z=standardized income variable with mean=0, sd=1; x=area-level average income from respondent; y=area-level average income in entire country; o=standard deviation of area-level income in entire country). Based on neighbourhood-level data from Statistics Netherlands, we calculated y and o in 2005 in the Netherlands: y=12.3206 and o=2.42953. Here, this variable is linked to GLOBE participants at wave 2004.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE} 
socenv_GLOBE_2$socenv_av_inc1000Z_2 <- (as.numeric(GLOBE2004$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)-12.3206)/2.42953

```

**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Harmonization status**: complete 
**Harmonization comment**:  
For GLOBE, these data are available for 4-digit postal codes in 2014. This variable includes the percentage of residents with high educational level (tertiary educational level + high vocational education + university education) in the 4-digit postal code area.  This variable has been linked to cohort respondents using their 4-digit postal codes.  References of all data sources are listed in the WP7 deliverable report. Here, the 2014-data are linked to GLOBE participants at wave 2011.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
socenv_GLOBE_3$socenv_perc_high_education_3<-as.numeric(GLOBE2011$PROPORTION_HIGH_EDUCATION_2014)

```
